thread.title: Memmott: Two efforts to honor Civil War vets
thread.title_full: Memmott: Two efforts to honor Civil War vets

author: Jim Memmott
title: Memmott: Two efforts to honor Civil War vets
text:
Time is not always easy on the dead. Or so it would seem in cemeteries throughout the area as grave markers fade, tip or sink, the years wearing them down.
Such is the case in St. Mary’s Cemetery in Geneseo, which is around the corner from where I live.
The cemetery is very well-maintained, but some of the stones are showing their age.
Becky Lawrence, who manages the cemetery, and her husband, Brian, have a particular concern for the 22 graves of Civil War veterans. They are scattered throughout the cemetery, generally tucked into family plots.
The Lawrences have identified seven of these graves whose markers need work. The top of one is all that peeks out of the ground. Others are tilting or their inscriptions are faded.
The couple became interested in restoring the stones after someone reminded them that this year marks the 150th anniversary of the end of the War Between the States.
“That really hit us,” Brian says. “We said, ‘We’ve got to do something.’”
And so, they’re having a fundraising dinner Saturday. Their modest goal is to come up with the $1,300 necessary to restore the markers most in need of repair.
In working on this project, the Lawrences have come to know the veterans’ backstories. Indeed, it’s almost as if they and the long-gone have become friends.
“This is Martin Graham,” Becky says, introducing a stone and, by implication, a person. And over there is John O’Connor, who enlisted in the 12th New York Cavalry at age 14 and survived the war without injury. (One of his brothers, however, was killed.)
O’Connor’s great-granddaughter, Nancy Monahan of East Rochester, wrote Brian, filling in some of the other details of her ancestor, how he moved to Geneseo from Le Roy in the 1870s, operated a restaurant, owned property.
Not as much is known about some of the other Civil War veterans.
“That’s no reason to neglect them,” Brian says. “We need to preserve their history. If their monuments (disappear), no one will ever know they’re here.”
Paint removal
In Rochester’s Mt. Hope Cemetery, a Civil War-related preservation effort of another sort is underway.
Architectural conservators Ron Koenig of Michigan and Peter Ellison of Canandaigua have been working this week on bringing back to life an impressive statue that graces a section of the cemetery holding the graves of about 400 veterans of the Civil War.
The Civil War monument at Mt. Hope Cemetery is currently being restored. (Photo: JIM MEMMOTT)
Sally James Farnham created the statue in 1908. It shows a flag-bearing soldier, his head bowed, standing beside a bugler. They seem spent, exhausted after a long war, as they honor the dead who lie all around.
Farnham was a native of Ogdensburg, St. Lawrence County, and a friend and protégé of Frederic Remington. She also sculpted a Civil War monument for Holy Sepulchre Cemetery in Rochester.
As much as they can, Koenig and Ellison hope to return the sculpture to its original appearance by removing the coat of paint that had been applied to the statue at some time after its creation.
The project is being financed in part by a grant from the Rochester Area Community Foundation obtained by the Friends of Mt. Hope Cemetery. (The Friends sponsor tours of the cemetery throughout the year. Coming up on Saturday and next Tuesday, there will be torch-lit nighttime tours.)
On Monday, the statue restorers were conducting a test of sorts, removing the paint from a bronze dog that had the name Carlo Pratt on its collar. “Carlo,” as the restorers have come to refer to the dog, was once taken from the cemetery and then found in a field in Henrietta.
The statue restoration effort should be finished this week.

Remarkable Rochesterians
This fabulously successful vegetarian cookbook author who celebrated her 65th birthday on Oct. 13 certainly merits a spot on the list of Remarkable Rochesterians found at RocRoots.com :
Mollie Katzen (Photo: Provided)
Mollie Katzen (1950-) Author of the best-selling Moosewood Cookbook , a 1977 volume inspired by the Moosewood restaurant in Ithaca. She introduced vegetarian recipes to millions of cooks. Born in Rochester, she took lessons at the Eastman School of Music, graduated from Monroe High School in 1968 and went on to study at Cornell University and graduate from the San Francisco Art Institute. She has written several more cookbooks and has hosted cooking programs on public television. Now living in Berkeley, California, she was named by Health Magazine as “one of the five women who have changed the way we eat.”
Benefit dinner
What: An event designed to raise money to repair Civil War grave markers in St. Mary’s Cemetery, Geneseo.
Where: St. Luke the Evangelist Parish Center, 13 North St., Geneseo.
When: 6 p.m. Saturday.
Tickets: $20 per person.
Information: (585) 330-1502.
Mount Hope at Night
What: Torch light tours of Mt. Hope Cemetery, 791 Mt. Hope Ave.
When: Saturday and Tuesday. Beginning at 5:55 p.m., tours go off every 15 minutes until the last tour at 8:45 p.m.
Admission: $9 in advance at Wegmans; $10 at the door. Free for members of the Friends of Mt. Hope Cemetery and children younger than 15 accompanied by an adult.
Information: www.fomh.org or (585) 461-3494.
